7.3.19  12:37 am   How do you break away from the shyness?

     extravertedness, and extraverted tactics. including maybe no less than outright extroversion

7.3.19  12:33 am   Are you an early bird or night owl?

     how about the middle of the day

7.3.19  12:14 am   I've seen you mention the frequencies of notes, a few times here on this page. Do you have this memorized for all notes on the piano or do you look it up?

     sometime around 2012 i took the time to familiarize myself with them, rounded to the nearest integer. i still remember the majority of the numbers, but whichever ones i don't remember can be easily obtained by dividing or multiplying the ones i do remember from other octaves. i realize most people have not done this, and i apologize

     If you have it memorized, what purpose does that serve and how do you apply it? 

      the reason was because i wanted a solid way to name the notes in any octave, and it seems there is no universally agreed upon numbering system. for example, roland and yamaha disagree on the octave numbers

     always lease

     just one very stretchy one

     impossible to know

     no, and not figuratively or virtually either

7.2.19  9:07 pm   do you play guitar?

     no

      and if you do when did you start? (i feel like i started really late)

7.2.19  9:06 pm   Oh boy. I watched a video about chords the other day, and it was really interesting. The video made me realise that I should definitely learn more about music stuff, so I decided to download a free demo version of some random music theory book today. The book thing introduced me to basic music notation stuff first. I was doing fine and having fun until I came across tuplets/grouplets. I just straight up had a short crying session because the darn thing blew my mind (in a negative way). Like, how are you supposed to divide a whole note into three half notes???

     write 3 half notes and put a big number 3 above the whole thing

      A whole note is worth 4 beats, and a half note is worth 2 beats. 3 times 2 equals 6, not 4!! I'm so confused?!?!

     right. the 3 is a cheat. 3 is actually short for 3:2 which means "3 in the time of 2"

      I just wanted to have fun!! I've even watched some videos regarding this topic, but I'm still not quite sure if I get the hang of it. I did try to make my own definition, but I think I might need your help with improving it. It basically goes like this: "a tuplet/grouplet is a group o f multip le shorter notes used as a substitute for a single longer note (for example a group of 3 eighth notes can be used instead of a single quarter note)" . Does my definition make any sense? How would you explain tuplets in your own words? What's the most important thing to know about tuplets? Also, where can I find really good examples of tuplets in songs? Thank you a lot in advance!!!

     a good way to start is with the most common case: 8th note triplets. 3 of those will fit in the time of 1 quarter note. you distinguish this by putting the number 3 above them like this (sorry for messy, new computer, no new pen yet. old pen does not work. need a new pen) that's the way it's normally written, but, to be more precise, it's actually 3:2. (3 in the time of 2.) but because that's so common, people just write 3. You can do this with any note value. another common way to see it is like this. that's 2 16th note triplets and 2 regular 16th notes. the 2 16th note triplets are occuring at a 3:2 rate which means there's 3 in the time you'd normally have 2. Sometimes you might see a group of 5 16th notes under a number 5, like this. this doesn't happen too often, but i think you can generally assume that the 5 means 5:4, and those 5 quintuplets are taking the space of 4 16th notes. but you can know for sure by looking at the rest of the bar and seeing how much space they take up. Usually the only time you'll see the : symbol being used is when it's a strange/uncommon situation and you need to clarify the ratio. actually the most common place i think you'd see it is if you are in a 6/8 time signature, which kind of makes normal 8th notes behave like triplets, because there are 3 per beat, with no number 3 written. So if you want to put 4 notes per beat instead, you'd have to say 4:3 to say 4 in the time of 3. like this. this is exhausting. need a new pen

7.2.19  7:56 pm   i have been searching for awhile and getting more and more upset at the lack of clarity of information.  would you mind going into some detail about what you know of compulsory licensing for doing covers.  as well as the idea of a 'derivative work' rather than a 'cover' and how that requires songwriter permission rather than a compulsory license.  i can't even figure out how to go about getting compulsory licenses or how much they would cost.  and i know that many people just don't even worry about it and post things without licenses but it makes me sort of scared to do that.  i really just don't want to bother with this crap because it sounds like a horrendous messy use of brainpower and time.  fuck word-soup-lawyer-speak.  so frustrating.

     hahahahahahahahaha sounds like you already know more than me. a general rule of thumb is, look around at people doing something similar to you and whose audience size is similar to yours, and see if they are getting busted or not. also contact those people and see if they have any experience with getting busted or not. and don't try to do the eagles

7.2.19  7:25 pm   i really don't understand the whole 'having suggestions for what bill should be doing' thing.

     what they may not realize is that i have an inherent tendency to want to do things other than what people have suggested

7.2.19  6:48 pm   If you had the opportunity to go on hot ones, would you?

     only if i could do it without eating the wings

7.2.19  6:26 pm   when you first started out making your own music was it simpler than what you're doing now? i started writing my own songs after years of just covering stuff and even though i can play really complicated songs by other people my own songs are very simple. a few basic chords, simple melodies, not much crazy going on. is this normal or do i just suck? and i want to note that i do not equate complexity with quality, but i guess i'd like to eventually do songs in crazy time signatures with weird progressions and other funky things. 

     the earlier things i did would have had no lyrics and been about an equal level of complexity as what i do now

     i will try

7.2.19  4:41 pm   I have nerve damage in my left ring finger's tip. It constantly feels like pins and needles. Do you think this will stop me from being able to competantly play a guitar or bass?

     no

      Would it be easier if I tried a left-hand oriented version of said instruments?

     it depends how much experience you have. if you have any experience at all playing right handed, then it may be extremely difficult to switch. it will be like starting from absolutely the beginning

7.2.19  3:57 pm   will the video come out in September?

     which video

7.2.19  3:38 pm   i remember watching a late night show video where a guest was being interviewed and at some point they quoted a song i think and started singing it in whatever key, and after a few seconds the band joined them in that very key. how does this happen, is there like a player with absolute pitch making some sort of gesture to the rest of the band or does each one start playing very silently until they find the key (i don't remember if there were any wrong notes at the beginning)

     even if you don't have absolute pitch, you can get away with it. all you have to do is flick a note, and you'll immediately know what key everything is in. the other players may also do the same, and/or if the keyboard player finds the key they can tell the other players. if all the players know the song, then that's great. if they don't, they can fake it using intuition and try to guess where it's going to go, and/or make ambiguous decisions until they get it. also what is quite common, if the keyboardist knows the song better than the others, they might say numbers or give number symbols with one hand. you may never believe this, but i think all the skills necessary to do this are actually skills that are not particularly common among people with true absolute pitch. absolute pitch may help you find 1 note if you're in handcuffs, but in terms of finding the chords and the rest of the song, it comes down to musicianship/music, which is quite unrelated to absolute pitch

7.2.19  10:20 am   it is vitally necessary for me to start finding gigs soon.  i have not played enough gigs in my life and it is starting to weigh heavily on me.  i play keyboard, and also wouldn't mind jumping off the deep end as a bassist if the duties were manageable.  the problem is, i don't really have equipment.  i don't have a keyboard amp or bass amp.  is it important to get a certain kind of equipment to be accepted for more gigs?  what have you done about this?

     sure, some gigs may require you to bring your own amp, but some do not. a cool trick that many people have done before is, see what gigs you can get without one, and then use the money from that to buy a cheap one. then do a few more and then use that money to buy a better one

7.2.19  10:05 am   6.29.19  2:07 pm

Oof. Time to see if I can break into any practice rooms on the music campus then

7.2.19  9:23 am   Thank you Bill Wurtz! Really cool to see a part of your creative process. Do you manually write out all of your music?

     nowadays i write using a combination of text files and demo reference recordings. i used to write on paper but that is too much maintenance. but handwriting is actually coming back again, sometimes i notate things using a graphics tablet

7.2.19  8:17 am   what advice would you give to people who want to make music/songs but are struggling to? (especially writing lyrics) 

     get a simple word processor and start going crazy with it. autocorrect and auto-punctuate must be entirely turned off to get the full effect of this

7.2.19  5:37 am   do i have too much, too little or enough anxiety?

     slightly too much but just barely

     no but i will do other songs that are stronger when longer

     that's nice of you

     anything

7.1.19  10:49 pm   It seems like you aren't a very windy or brassy person, but how do you feel about learning trumpet/saxophone in concert pitch instead of the transposition mess?

For my purposes it works since I just need it for layering and botched solos, but I don't want to be a bad influence.

     i have no idea. i don't particularly know anything about the trumpet or sax fingerings, but i have often assumed that in a parallel universe everyone could simply learn everything in concert pitch. also, professional players who play with groups of mostly guitar/keyboards, they seem to live their life in concert pitch with no questions asked. so i have often wondered about that and i don't know the answer but i suspect there is a good reason why the transposition keys exist. but i don't know quite know what that is

7.1.19  10:46 pm   Your music to me is like a masterclass in a multitude of fields simultaneously (songwriting, jazz, producing, self-reflection, resilience, ethical philosophy, etc)

What do you see as one major takeaway? intentional or otherwise.  thx

     it's difficult to imagine, because i would never be the one taking. i am on the giving end

7.1.19  8:19 pm   had a question about the song might quit; the solo plays the main melody in three octaves:

Highest oct: Dadada da da daaa
Middle oct: Dododo do do dooo
Lower oct: Dududu du du du du du duuu dudu duu...

I always enjoy listening to that song, but I can't help but notice how the middle oct melody (second dadada) doesn't quite fall in the right beat, not quite in sync. did you notice that or did that on purpose? 

     yes. i think that's well within the normal range of 'stretch' than can occur in any vocal (or lead instrument) performance
